snippet: In its second major effort to revive a flagging economy, the Indian cabinet proposed letting foreign investors take a bigger stake in insurance and pension companies, but passage of the measure by Parliament is far from certain.
abstract: Indian policy makers propose letting foreign investors take a bigger stake in insurance and pension companies, in second major effort to revive economy; Parliament's passage of measure is far from certain; national governing coalition led by the Indian National Congress Party does not have a majority in legislature, and opposition parties and even some of its own allies say they do not support greater foreign investment.

byline.original: By HEATHER TIMMONS and VIKAS BAJAJ
byline.contributor: Heather Timmons reported from New Delhi, and Vikas Bajaj from Mumbai. Hari Kumar contributed reporting from New Delhi.

lead_paragraph: In its second major effort to revive a flagging economy, the Indian cabinet proposed letting foreign investors take a bigger stake in insurance and pension companies, but passage of the measure by Parliament is far from certain.

headline.main: India Moves Again to Ease Way for Foreign Investment
headline.print_headline: India Moves Again to Ease Way for Foreign Investment
